tossups.question: “Patting” these objects is compared to touching phalluses in an article titled “Sex and Death in the Rational World” of certain intellectuals written by Carol Cohn. With Max Singer and Oscar Ruebhausen, a theorist about these things founded the Hudson Institute. They provide the “stability” in the “Stability-Instability Paradox.” Near accidents involving them were the subject of Eric Schlosser’s book Command and Control. Scott Sagan wrote a book presenting a debate about these things in opposition to co-writer Kenneth Waltz. (*) Game theory was applied to the use of these things by people like Herman Kahn at Rand Corporation. The use of these things is inconceivable because of fear of being wiped out by a “second strike” according to deterrence theory. For 10 points, name these weapons whose use could cause Mutually Assured Destruction.
tossups.answer: nuclear weapons [or nukes; or atomic weapons; Hydrogen bombs; Inter-Continental Ballistic Missiles; ICBMs; accept obvious equivalents that mention atomic or nuclear things that are used as bombs]
tossups.answer_formatted: nuclear weapons [or nukes; or atomic weapons; Hydrogen bombs; Inter-Continental Ballistic Missiles; ICBMs; accept obvious equivalents that mention atomic or nuclear things that are used as bombs]
acceptable: nuclear things that are used as bombs

tossups.question: Characters in this novel argue over a story in which a man never forgives a woman for breaking a garish vase she gave him. A bird-obsessed man in this novel kills an ostrich to woo a woman, who dies after dancing on her eighty-ninth birthday. The black activist Uhuru Simba is wrongfully arrested for the Granny Ripper murders in this novel, and the day after a man is thought dead, his wife makes love to his friend Jumpy Joshi. “To be born again, first you have to die” is a refrain in this novel, in which (*) Mahound conquers Jahilia in even chapters. Ayesha leads pilgrims into the sea in this novel, in which the protagonist kills his mountaineer girlfriend Allie Cone. A plane exploding over the English Channel causes Gibreel Farishta and Saladin Chamcha to turn into an angel and a devil in this novel. For 10 points, Salman Rushdie received a fatwa for writing what novel?

Expanding the potential of one of these systems in powers of one over the distance gives the potential of these systems as proportional to the integral of a first-order Legendre polynomial. The fact that a quantity associated with these systems may be non-zero for a certain particle would allow for a significant amount of CP violation, thus explaining the baryon asymmetry of the universe. For anisotropic materials, the ability of these systems to form can be represented as a rank-two tensor; that quantity is the (*) polarizability. The field produced by one of these systems falls off as the third power of the distance. These systems will experience maximum torque when aligned perpendicular to an external electric field. For 10 points, name these systems which consist of separated equal and opposite charges.

In a story by this author, Hugh Vereker insults a monograph about him as “twaddle” without realizing its author is sitting next to him. This author wrote about an obsessive fanboy of the writer Mark Ambient, whose wife refuses to treat their sick son because she hates his novels. This writer believed that his most famous work could not be adapted into a play, since its best scene consisted of the protagonist experiencing a revelation while (*) sitting still in a chair. This author of “The Figure in the Carpet” and “The Author of Beltraffio” wrote a novel in which the protagonist exhorts “Live all you can” to Little Bilham before turning down Maria Gostrey. That man, Lambert Strether, goes to Europe to stop a romance. The title character marries Gilbert Osmond in his novel about Isabel Archer. For 10 points, name this author of The Ambassadors and The Portrait of a Lady.

Modern rabbis have suggested changing this day’s Nachem prayer due to the creation of the State of Israel. One can only study certain sections of Torah on this day, including portions of Jeremiah, and this day is preceded by a three-week period called Bayn-Ha-Metsarim, or “in the Straits.” The origins of this day, also known as the “Black Fast,” trace back to the return of the (*) Twelve Spies sent by Moses to Canaan, who all maligned the land except Caleb and Joshua; this so angered God that he declared that day to be one of misfortune. Recitations from kinnot on this day follow readings from the Book of Lamentations, and this day marks the anniversary of five calamities. For 10 points, name this fast day that commemorates disasters like the destruction of the First and Second temples, the “saddest day” of the Jewish calendar.
tossups.answer: Tisha B’Av [or the ninth of Av]

tossups.question: Mutations in FZD4, LRP5, or NDP can cause a genetic disease in which this structure shows exudates. Occlusion of its namesake vein creates a “blood and thunder” appearance. Atherosclerotic patients can have Hollenhorst plaques in the vessels found in this structure, which can cause amaurosis fugax. Ischemia (is-KEE-mi-a) in this structure shows up as cotton-wool spots. A lack of red reflex, or leukocoria, in children is indicative of a (*) tumor of this structure, caused by mutations in RB. The choroid provides oxygen to the outer layers of this structure, which contains glia called Mueller cells. In this structure, bipolar cells communicate with ganglion cells. The fovea contains the densest concentration of cone cells in this structure. For 10 points, name this thin layer of photoreceptors at the back of the eye.

In this work, a Christian tries to get a Jewish friend to convert, but freaks out upon hearing his friend is planning to go to Rome since he'll see all the corrupt priests. This collection's author claims he wrote it to ease ladies’ boredom because a woman once helped him get over a difficult love affair. “Putting the devil in hell” is a euphemism for sex in this work, in which Federigo cooks his (*) falcon to serve to his love. The three Abrahamic faiths are symbolized by a parable about a man giving his sons three identical rings in this collection, in which the patient Griselda is sadistically tested by her husband and Ciappelletto is sainted after “confessing” to minor sins. In this collection, a king or queen of the day sets the theme of stories to be told by the travelers Dianeo and Fiametta. For 10 points, name this collection of stories told during the Black Death, by Boccaccio.

One Pre-Raphaelite artist in this medium depicted the parting of Lancelot and Guinevere and showed King David in a brocaded robe. Some works in this medium depict children’s heads sticking out over a Fibonacci spiral staircase and a man bicycling away from the bottom of some stairs; the same artist’s most famous work features a sign saying “Railowsky” in the background. Honore Daumier caricatured one of this medium’s practitioners (*) “elevating” it to a “high art.” Another work in this medium shows a man appearing to fly over a puddle in the street. Julia Margaret Cameron created softly lit “fancy portraits” in this medium, which was also practiced by Nadar from a balloon. Another practitioner of this work stressed the importance of “the decisive moment” in timing a candid shot. For 10 points, name this medium of works by Henri Cartier-Bresson.

This general pioneered the use of underwater bridges in a campaign where the other side avoided attacking his airbase at Tamsak-Bulak. This person was criticized when his train cars were discovered to be carrying loot in the “Trophy Affair.” This person launched failed attacks in Operation Mars, which became known as the Rzhev Meat Grinder. After a clash at Lake Khasan, this general defeated General Komatsubara of the Kwantung Army in the Battle of (*) Khalkhin Gol. This general assisted a future premier in arresting his rival Lavrentiy Beria. Forces led by this general were successful in commemorating May Day by raising a flag over the Reichstag. This general’s greatest success was his planning of Operation Uranus to surround the 6th Army of General Paulus. For 10 points, name this Soviet “Marshal of Victory” who won the Battle of Stalingrad.

One type of this technique requires a “purge gas” like nitrogen or helium to remove moisture and eliminate artifacts. The Joule effect is used to calibrate a device used for this process. Protonation effects must be considered in a form of this technique which measures ligand binding affinity by applying a feedback circuit to a system undergoing titration. Types of this device include the Tian-Calvet and the Sage form. Peaks signify the (*) glass transition temperature by comparing reference and sample pans in the differential scanning form of this technique. The “bomb” form of this technique uses constant volume, while nested coffee cups can be used to conduct it at constant pressure. For 10 points, name this instrument for measuring the heat produced in a reaction.

In one painting, this kind of object is shown under a Visscher map and a golden chandelier. In that painting, a girl with a wreath on her head holds a trumpet and a book, while a man in a striped shirt sits in front of this kind of object. A two-part picture features a circular one of these underneath a black mirror and next to a counter where a woman displays another of these objects to two men, while another of these things is being (*) put into a crate. Many of these objects are being taken down in the background of Watteau’s Gersaint’s Shop Sign, and the back of one of these things is featured in Las Meninas while Velazquez stands at it. For 10 points, name these objects which artists are often depicted creating in self-portraits.
tossups.answer: paintings [prompt on “pictures” or “art”; accept easel or canvas until “right of a self-portrait”]
tossups.answer_formatted: paintings [prompt on pictures or art; accept easel or canvas until “right of a self-portrait]

tossups.question: A history of this dynasty begins with a meeting of 318 “Orthodox Fathers.” This dynasty held no power during a period dominated by the Yejju people. Rulers of this dynasty governed from tents until its ruler Fasilides created a castle in a new capital called Gondar. The likely mythical first ruler of this dynasty was supposedly the son of a woman named Makeda. This dynasty’s first real ruler conquered an empire with a capital at Lalibela and is named Yekuno Amlak. This dynasty’s genealogy was documented in the (*) Kebra Negast. After being tricked into signing the Treaty of Wuchale, one ruler of this dynasty who succeeded Yohannes IV defeated General Oreste Baratieri at the Battle of Adowa. This dynasty was ruled by people named Tewodros and Menelik. For 10 points, name this dynasty ruled by Haile Selassie in Ethiopia.
tossups.answer: Solomonic dynasty [or House of Solomon; Solomonids]

tossups.question: In one work, this figure declares that “Thy gentle words / Are sweeter even than freedom long desired.” After being told “Many ... would be just / but live among their suffering fellow-men / as if none felt; they know not what they do,” this figure responds, “Thy words are like a cloud of winged snakes." One work about this figure ends with a speech about how “to defy Power, which seems omnipotent” is alone “Life, Joy, Empire, and Victory,” delivered by (*) Demogorgon. In another play, this character declares that “I would not change my painful plight ... for your servile humility” in response to Hermes chastising him for his “insolent” conduct. For 10 points, name this figure who is “unbound” in a closet drama by Percy Shelley, believed to be the focus of a trilogy by Aeschylus that included this figure as “the Fire-Bringer.”

One of this man’s songs begins with a 58-measure baritone solo over a humming voice choir and calls for three yodelers. This man quoted a theme from Palestrina’s Missa Brevis in the Sanctus of his Mass in E Minor. Violins playing a duplet-triplet rhythm on high C-sharp open this man’s sixth symphony. Franz Liszt rejected this man’s dedication of his Second Symphony, which features a large pause (*) before the cellos introduce the second theme of the first movement. The principal theme of the scherzo second movement of his eighth symphony is nicknamed Deutscher Michel. The third movement of this composer’s most famous symphony was entirely rewritten into a “Hunt” Scherzo after the Vienna Philharmonic rejected the first version as unplayable. For 10 points, name this Austrian composer of the “Lyric” Symphony and the “Romantic” Symphony.

In one creation myth, a male of this animal tries to name parts of a loom, only to have a female of this animal constantly veto his names. Another animal of this type traded clothes with a man named Nothing and killed him by making his stairs extra slippery. In a Choctaw myth, this animal steals fire by placing it in a clay container. One animal of this type dropped a pot full of wisdom, and a Hopi (*) “Grandmother” of these animals creates the stars by throwing dew into the air. One animal of this kind convinced bees to fly into a jar and told a python he needed to measure him in order to tie him to a stick. That trickster figure got stuck to a tar baby he tried to fight and obtained all the stories of the world. For 10 points, name these eight-legged animals including Anansi.

Thomas Harriot wrote A Brief and True Report of his journey to this site, which is where Simon Fernandez abandoned his ship’s passengers. At this location, members of the American Missionary Association designed a New England-style village and created a job training program to demonstrate the “New Social Order” vision of Reverend Horace James. From 1863 to 1865, this place was the location of General John Foster’s experimental Freedmen’s Colony intended to prepare ex-slaves for professional life. Sir (*) Francis Drake brought many of this location’s residents back to England. Virginia Dare was born at this site, where John White discovered the word “CROATOAN” carved into a tree trunk. For 10 points, name this island in modern-day North Carolina, the location of a colony founded by Walter Raleigh whose members mysteriously disappeared.
tossups.answer: Roanoke Island [or Freedmen’s Colony of Roanoke Island; or Roanoke Colony; prompt on “the Lost Colony”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Roanoke Island [or Freedmen’s Colony of Roanoke Island; or Roanoke Colony; prompt on the Lost Colony]

tossups.question: For a module M of a ring R, any alternating map out of R to the n can be written as the composition of a map corresponding to this quantity and a linear map. That map corresponding to this quantity is sometimes denoted with a wedge symbol. An alternating map applied to n (*) vectors is equal to this quantity times that map evaluated at the basis vectors. This quantity is equal to the sum over all permutations sigma of the sign of sigma times the product of a sub i comma sigma i. This quantity is invariant under the transpose, and can be computed using expansion by minors. For 10 points, name this quantity that for the two by two matrix with entries a, b, c, d is equal to a times d minus b times c.

Some of these people are currently planned for relocation to Thengar Char Island. Some of these people currently live at Cox’s Bazar, while others live at Kutupalong, which is on the Naf River. This group is opposed by an organization called the Tatmadaw. An organization of these people led by Atta Ullah is called the “Faith Movement,” or ARSA, and it ignited clashes by attacking a border post near Maungdaw. An organization opposed to these people holds (*) 25% of the seats in its country’s Parliament. Zeid Ra’ad Al Hussein stated that they are the victims of a “textbook example” of ethnic cleansing. The persecution of these people in the Rakhine State has barely been acknowledged by Nobel Peace Prize laureate Aung San Suu Kyi. For 10 points, name this Muslim minority ethnic group which has been the target of state-sponsored violence in Myanmar.

bonuses.leadin: In one short story by this author, the playboy Oswald Cornelius hooks up with either his host’s wife or his daughter, only to find out it was actually a second daughter with sexually-transmitted leprosy. For 10 points each:
answers: a leg of lamb [prompt on “meat” or synonyms]
parts: Name this British short-story author. He wrote about Drioli, who is killed for the tattooed painting on his back, in “Skin,” and about an old man meeting a school prefect who caned him in “Galloping Foxley.”
Probably the most famous of Dahl’s adult stories concerns Mary Maloney, who murders her philandering husband with this item of food and persuades the cops to eat the murder weapon.
Roald Dahl’s first published story, “A Piece of Cake,” was about his experiences as a fighter pilot in this war, which is also addressed in A Bell for Adano and Catch-22.

bonuses.leadin: Name some old-time religions that should be good enough for you if it’s good enough for Grandma, for 10 points each:
parts: Name of the religion or the god is acceptable. In the 14th century BCE, the Egyptian pharaoh Akhenaten promulgated a monotheistic cult centered around this disk of the sun, an aspect of Ra.

This dualistic religion was started by a man called the “Apostle of Light” in 3rd century Sassanid Persia. Its namesake prophet claimed he would complete the incomplete teachings of Buddha, Zoroaster, and Jesus.

This religion of the neo-Assyrian empire was named after and based on the worship of their chief god, a cognate of Enlil, who had the consort Mullissu. This religion’s namesake was represented as a winged horned disk.

bonuses.leadin: Tarquin the Proud refused to buy these documents at first, leading 6 of them to be burnt. For 10 points each:
answers: Sibylline Books [or Libri Sibyllini; Fata Sibyllina; Libri Fatales]
augurs [accept augury; taking the auspices; prompt on generic answers like “priests” or “collegium”]
parts: Name these documents written in hexameter that were stored in the Temple of Jupiter Capitolinus and guarded by the Decemviri Sacris Faciundis. The general Flavius Stilicho supposedly ordered that they be destroyed.

Cicero discussed the incredible veto power that holders of this position held on public transactions. The holders of this position name the study of the flight of birds to try to interpret the will of the gods.
Probably the most famous use of augury in Roman history was when this founder of Rome used the number of birds flying around his head to justify becoming king over his twin brother, Remus.
answers_formatted: Sibylline Books [or Libri Sibyllini; Fata Sibyllina; Libri Fatales]
augurs [accept augury; taking the auspices; prompt on generic answers like “priests or collegium]

bonuses.leadin: In one anecdote, the narrator of this book writes its title in chalk on the back of a gang of first grade boys. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Richard Brautigan novel, a series of connected surrealist anecdotes featuring the titular wino Shorty and ending with “The Mayonnaise Chapter.”
This work by Izaak Walton is a somewhat more literal depiction of fishing, with paeans to fishing as well as helpful instructions. In it, Piscator teaches Auceps and Venator how to fish.
This author depicted fishing in many stories such as “Big Two-Hearted River,” The Sun Also Rises, and The Old Man and the Sea.

bonuses.leadin: Complexes of different geometries split these degenerate orbitals into two or four levels. For 10 points each:
answers: high-spin and low-spin [or equivalents like “high and low spin”; all parts required]
parts: Name these atomic orbitals that can contain up to 10 electrons. In octahedral complexes, they are split into e sub g and t sub 2g subsets.

Transitions between d orbitals in centrosymmetric molecules violate Laporte’s rule, which is why they’re described by this adjective. These transitions are those for which the overlap integral is zero.
Octahedral complexes can be distinguished into these two categories based on the number of unpaired electrons they have, or whether they absorb high-energy or low-energy photons.
answers_formatted: high-spin and low-spin [or equivalents like “high or low spin; all parts required]

bonuses.leadin: A man with this profession named Magnificent Montague faced public scrutiny after his catch-phrase, “Burn, baby! Burn!” was chanted by rioters. For 10 points each:
answers: radio disc jockey [or deejay; or radio personality; accept descriptive answers like “radio show host,” “rock n’roll deejay” and the like]
Elvis Aaron Presley [accept either underlined portion]
parts: Name this profession revolutionized in the 1950s by people like Alan Freed and Wolfman Jack. Freed and many other members of this profession were revealed to have accepted bribes in the Payola scandal.

In the 1950s, Alan Freed helped popularize rock’n’roll with white audiences by playing records by Bill Haley and this other musician. This Tupelo, Mississippi-native recorded songs like “Heartbreak Hotel” and “Hound Dog.”

The term “disc jockey” was coined by this celebrity gossip commentator. This opponent of isolationism began each show by saying: “Good morning, Mr. and Mrs. America from border to border and coast to coast and all the ships at sea."
answers_formatted: radio disc jockey [or deejay; or radio personality; accept descriptive answers like “radio show host,” “rock n’roll deejay or the like]
acceptable: descriptive answers like “radio show host,” “rock n’roll deejay

bonuses.leadin: This man’s wife Chang’e became the goddess of the moon, where she is worshipped on Mid-Autumn Day. For 10 points each:
answers: Feng Meng [or Peng Meng or Beng Meng]
immortality [accept the Eight Immortals or any answer, in English or Chinese, that is related to not dying or living forever or suchlike]
parts: Name this Chinese hero, an archer who shot down nine of the ten suns, depicted as birds in a mulberry tree, when the world became too hot. He also killed the bull demon Fei Lian.
This jealous apprentice of Houyi beat him to death with a peach club after failing to hit him with arrows in an attempt to steal his reward for shooting the suns.
That reward was an elixir that conferred this property, which turned Chang’e into a goddess. Eight people with this quality, including He Xian’gu and Zhang Guolao, feature heavily in Chinese myth.
answers_formatted: immortality [accept the Eight Immortals or any answer, in English or Chinese, that is related to not dying or living forever or suchlike]
acceptable: Chinese, that is related to not dying

bonuses.leadin: Name some algorithms from computational biology, for 10 points each:
answers: BLAST [or Basic Local Alignment Search Tool]
parts: This algorithm is used to identify matching protein or DNA sequences within a database, usually the NCBI’s. It identifies high-scoring short words and expands them to high-scoring segment pairs.
In gene sequences, the individual letters compared in BLAST are A, C, G, and T, representing these monomers of DNA and RNA that consist of nitrogenous bases and a sugar-phosphate.

This non-PAM substitution matrix is used in BLAST for protein sequence alignment; matrices with higher numbers compare more closely related sequences. Matrix elements are calculated from probabilities of one amino acid replacing another in a sequence.

bonuses.leadin: To the dismay of actual athletes around the world, the organizers of the 2024 Olympics in Paris are considering the inclusion of esports as a medal event. For 10 points each:
answers: EVO Moment #37 [accept the Daigo Parry, accept any variation of Daigo Umehara coming back against Justin Wong or Daigo beating Justin, etc, etc, etc]
parts: The fourth through seventh editions of the International, where teams compete in this esport, hold the top four places for largest overall prize pools. This non-league MOBA is the sequel to a 2003 mod for Warcraft 3.
The fighting game community may have been saved by this iconic Street Fighter 3 event at Evo 2004, where a player using Ryu parried 15 hits of Chun-Li’s Super Art to come back from one pixel of life.

Mark Cuban once played League of Legends at one of these Intel-sponsored event series in San Jose, comparing the game to “five-dimensional chess against the world.” They hold world championships at Katowice.
answers_formatted: EVO Moment #37 [accept the Daigo Parry, or any variation of Daigo Umehara coming back against Justin Wong or Daigo beating Justin, etc, etc, etc]
acceptable: any variation of Daigo Umehara coming back against Justin Wong
Daigo beating Justin, etc, etc, etc

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the feminist sex wars, for 10 points each.
answers: speech act theory [prompt on “performative utterances” or “performative speech”]
parts: This sex-positive gender theorist defined a “Charmed Circle” of sexuality and argues that more expansive views of “good and bad” sex acts that take into account sexual and cultural diversity are needed.

“Sex-negative” feminists campaigned against the ethicality and legality of this type of “obscene” material. Andrea Dworkin and Catharine MacKinnon argued that this material was inherently misogynistic.
Philosophers like Jennifer Hornsby and Ishani Maitra have analyzed how pornography “silences” women using this theory of performative language developed by J.L. Austin.
answers_formatted: speech act theory [prompt on performative utterances or performative speech]

bonuses.leadin: This musical court was first established when Karl Philip moved his entire court from Heidelberg. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this pre-classical court of musicians famous for their precision and technique. It is now best remembered for its virtuosic orchestral techniques, such as its namesake “roll” and “rocket.”

This prolific composer and virtuoso violinist was primarily in charge of training the musicians at Mannheim Court. His symphonies such as Sinfonia 8 in D major contain many examples of Mannheim mannerisms.
Stamitz was likely the first composer to consistently use the four-movement classical symphony form, which includes this 3/4 time dance suite and trio as its third movement.

bonuses.leadin: In an early novel in this genre, Mackandal seems to turn into a bird at the moment of his execution. For 10 points each:
answers: The Kingdom of This World [or El reino de este mundo]
parts: Name this genre of Isabel Allende’s The House of the Spirits, in which fantastical elements are blended with an otherwise real-world setting.

This aforementioned 1949 novel by Alejo Carpentier has a preface that promotes “marvelous realism.” In this novel, the former slave Ti Noel turns himself into a goose after living through the Haitian revolution.

Ti Noel is forced to work on the construction of this magnificent palace for King Henri-Christophe. The king plans this citadel in homage to Louis XIV and Frederick the Great in Aime Cesaire’s play about him.
answers_formatted: The Kingdom of This World [or El reino de este mundo]

bonuses.leadin: Terms for this concept can be descriptive or classificatory based on whether or not they use the same term for “mother’s sister” and “mother.” For 10 points each:
answers: kinship [accept word forms, prompt on descriptive similar answers like family or clan]
parts: Name this anthropological name for the familial relationships between individuals.
This man wrote about kinship in Systems of Consanguinity and Affinity of the Human Family, dividing kinship terminologies into Hawaiian, Sudanese, and Eskimo types, among others.
This anthropologist studied kinship and non-kin groups in black families in the United States, although she is better known for her study of families and ethnic groups in the Dutch Caribbean.
answers_formatted: kinship [accept word forms, prompt on descriptive similar answers like family or clan]
acceptable: word forms, prompt on descriptive similar answers like family

bonuses.leadin: A type of microscopy using this effect is used to absorb cell adhesion on a plate. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phenomenon that occurs above the critical angle, in which a beam of light travelling from one medium to another bounces back into the first medium.
This other quantity is the angle at which a beam of light of a given polarization is transmitted perfectly, without reflection.
The Brewster angle is equal to this function of the ratio between n sub 2 and n sub 1.

bonuses.leadin: This work calls mountains a “reservoir of men for other men’s use” in a chapter titled “Mountains Come First.” For 10 points each:
answers: The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II [or La Mediterranee et le Monde Mediterraneen a l’Epoque de Philippe II]
parts: Name this work whose author later wrote the three volume Capitalism and Material Life. This book discusses “cycles spanning centuries” while approaching the subject through “geographical time.”
The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II was written by Fernand Braudel, a member of this school of French historians who focused on long-term social trends.
Another Annales historian, Marc Bloch, wrote a book about this “Society.” In this system prevalent in Medieval Europe, vassals managed fiefs for lords in return for armed protection.
answers_formatted: The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II [or La Mediterranee et le Monde Mediterraneen a l’Epoque de Philippe II]
acceptable: The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II
Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II
La Mediterranee et le Monde Mediterraneen a l’Epoque de Philippe II

bonuses.leadin: This musician supposedly stopped playing clarinet after his wooden clarinet from Benny Goodman was stolen. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this tenor saxophonist nicknamed “the Prez” who rose to fame as a member of Count Basie’s orchestra. He composed D.B. Blues after his time in the detention barracks during WWII.
Lester Young frequently collaborated with this Jazz singer and gave her the nickname “Lady Day.” This singer of “God Bless the Child” and “Strange Fruit” was heartbroken after Young’s death.
Charles Mingus composed this jazz standard in honor of Lester Young, who would often wear the titular piece of clothing. This piece was first released as a part of Mingus Ah Um.

bonuses.leadin: Theodor Adorno claimed that these poems were “essentially evil” due to their combination of religion as ornament and emphasis on commitment. For 10 points each:
answers: The Book of Hours [or Das Stunden-Buch]
parts: Name this set of ten poems by Rainer Maria Rilke. Written during a period of depression in their namesake castle, this collection explores existential themes of suffering and religion.
This elegy asks, “Who, if I cried out, would hear me among the hierarchies of angels?” and ends with a “quivering that now enraptures us, and comforts, and helps.”
This other set of poems by Rilke consists of three cycles of poems dedicated to Lou Andreas-Salome. The three sections are titled for Monastic Life, Pilgrimage, and Poverty and Death.

bonuses.leadin: Two answers required. One of these two families conquered the other dynasty’s capital city, Hue, in 1775 with Portuguese-designed bronze cannons. For 10 points each:
answers: the House of Trinh AND the House of Nguyen [can be answered in any order]
the Trung sisters [or Hai Ba Trung; or Trung Trac; Trung Nhi]
parts: Name these clans that initially allied to fight against the Mac dynasty. One of these families built the Dong Hoi wall to defend against the other, and they were both eventually defeated by the Tay Son rebels.

The Trinh and Nguyen controlled the Red River and Mekong River respectively within this modern-day country. This modern-day country’s city of Hanoi was its main capital until the capital was moved by the Nguyens.

Both the Trinh and the Nguyen claimed to be carrying out the legacy of these badass, semi-legendary Vietnamese warrior sisters, who briefly overthrew Vietnam’s Han dynasty overlords and rode war elephants.
answers_formatted: the House of Trinh AND the House of Nguyen [can be answered in any order]
the Trung sisters [or Hai Ba Trung; or Trung Trac; Trung Nhi]
acceptable: the House of Trinh AND the House of Nguyen
House of Trinh AND the House of Nguyen

bonuses.leadin: China created a “Great” one of these things in order to block access to non-government-approved sites. For ten points each:
answers: distributed denial of service attack (accept DOS or DDOS)
parts: Name these things that increase security by regulating traffic between a computer and network, named for a physical barrier used to stop flames.
Firewalls can prevent these attacks. The “Great Cannon of China” launched these at Github when it hosted censorship-evading sites.

Hackers used this tool to pinpoint the IP hosting the Great Firewall of China. This terminal command sends UDP packets with gradually increasing time-to-live values, so that each gets one hop closer to the source IP.

bonuses.leadin: A man with a hat mysteriously labeled “32” appears in a painting named after this man which was painted to cover up his poisoning of some infected soldiers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this historical figure, who is shown visiting plague victims in that painting and is “crossing the Alps” on a rearing horse in a painting by Jacques-Louis David.
This artist of The Turkish Bath and The Source depicted Napoleon in red in Bonaparte, First Consul before showing him in ornate ermine coronation robes in Napoleon I on his Imperial Throne.
Bonaparte Visiting the Plague Victims of Jaffa was by Antoine-Jean Gros, who also painted Napoleon visiting soldiers dying in the snow on this battlefield.
